captions.text: [music]
Carcinophobia from Ohio asks
How does the Korean standard of beauty differ from that of North America
and are there any things that North American do
that South Koreans would find strange, and vice versa.
Ok, I think that North American and Korean beauty standards are totally different,
In the sense that North America doesn't really have A beauty standard,
it kind of, like, changes, depending on the person himself
Yeah, you can like redheads or you can like freckles,
you can like bodybuilders or you can like skinny people,
or you can like girls that are curvy, or girls that just have big butts.
and you cannot lie.
Alright, don't start mister.
and you other brothers can't deny.
When a girl walks in with a little bitty waist and a bundemdubnmendmnedmn
You get sprung, like a baseball bat!
And that's the only part of the song I know.
A simple example: I was teaching my students about face shapes,
a square jaw, or a v-shape, or a diamond, or a heart, round, oval,
and my students would be like "well, teacher.  Which one is the ideal face shape?"
and I'm like, well, what do you mean, ideal?
and they're like, "well, what's the one that everyone wants?  The best one?"
and I'm like, "well, there isn't a best one"
There is no perfect face.
and they're like "well what celebrity has the best face?"
"which celebrity would be the ideal person that you look up to?"
and I'm like, what?  We don't really have an ideal, right?
I didn't think of that, no.
You might like a square jawbone on Brad Pitt,
but you may not like that.  You might like a guy who has a round face.
So it seems to us that Korea sticks to one idea of what is ideal,
that they aspire to,
yeah, and they have different points that, like,
if you can do these things, and you can look this way,
then you're kind of like an ideal, beautiful person.
So we noticed some common traits in these perfect faces,
#1, it really has to do with eyes,
so like, big eyes, and double eyelids,
that kind of like, doll-face eye look is really ideal here.
You can have surgery to get it done, you can have your eyes widened,
you can have the double eyelids done as well,
but we don't want to go into surgery in this video,
it's a totally different topic,
In comparison to North America, I don't think this is something people really think about,
like, I never really noticed a double-eyelid on somebody,
while here it seems to be a big deal,
not saying that there's anything wrong with it here,
it's just not anything that North Americans pay attention to a lot of the time,
I think one beauty standard that definitely horrifies Koreans from North America
would be tanning.  Oh boy!
Not just North America.  People in Europe tan all the time on the beaches and stuff
But, like, getting tans on the beach, or going to tanning salons,
tanning oils, or like, tanning lotions.
I just don't think that would translate well over into Korean culture,
they kind of try to do their best to not tan.
covering up with their long sleeves, and the ajumma visors,
so that you don't have any darkening of the skin whatsoever.
In fact we noticed that with some of our students in the classroom,
if there was one student who was a little bit darker than everybody else,
but by no means dark according to our standards,
other students would make fun of them, like
"hahaha teacher look!  That's Obama!"
And then we would have to change our lesson into something different like
How not to get your ass kicked in North America.
Oh culturally insensitive Korea!  Sometimes you make us lol!
You gotta work on that!
So, one Korean beauty standard that definitely doesn't translate into North America
is the concept of having like a big, or small face.
It seems that a lot of foreigners have experienced this when they start teaching,
students will be like, "teacher teacher!  Your face is so small!"
and they do, like, the fist size face,
and I'm like, "your face is small I'm gonna punch it!"
and I'm like, I don't really think my face is small or big,
it's just, like, a face.
but when we take pictures together my students will cover their jawbone area,
like, they'll do this, or they'll do this.
so when you see them doing kimchis, it's not because they're trying to be cute,
but it's because they're trying to hide the size of their face
which, supposedly, according to them, is big.
and we don't notice that at all.
So the area they supposedly think is big is this area here,
they think that it's, like, wider,
and they don't like high cheekbones, or those puffy things
where you're like [baby coddling talk]
like those things.
Uh.  Supposedly that's not good.
But we never notice big faces on Korean people,
It's not like we're "Wow!  You're face is so big!"
So big!
You just have a face.
But I think this gets into our next point about V-Line,
So V-Line is really closely tied with face size,
so basically V-line is this area here,
So if you have, like, a V-Style face,
it's considered to be very beautiful,
and a lot of Korean advertisements will show like
"Oh drink this green tea beverage and you'll get a v-line"
and they'll hold it up like this to show the V-Shape
That's why sometimes you'll see those chin rollers as well
because they'll try to make you have a more V of a face,
and you're pushing it with this awkward motion right here.
Oh Simon.
I'm just showing you what it does!
I know!  It's true!  It's a face roller!  It rolls your face!
So I'll tell you what we find really interesting:
these standards of beauty can apply to both men and women,
you might have thought we were just talking about women,
with like the V-line and the pale skin, but we're not.
It can be totally Korean men or Korean women.
While in North America there seems to be different standards
for what's a beautiful guy and what's a beautiful girl.
While here the mould seems to be similar.
Kind of like, can you say, monosexual?
or like, Ubersexual?
Oh!  Oh I like that!
Because I naughty naughty!
[Awesome rendition of Mr. Simple]
So that's it for this week's TL;DR,
if there's a question you want us to answer for next week's TL;DR
Leave your question in the Google Moderator page,
Or you can check the questions already asked,
and you can vote them up, or vote them down.
and don't forget to subscribe for more TL;DRs.
Do it for the Spudgy!
Spudgy's like, "Guise!  I am beautiful!  No matter what you say!"
Good for you Spudgy!
How many things did you hump in this video big guy?
Gong!
[Sexy Intoxicating Music]

title: Korean vs. North American Beauty Standards

comments.text:

Besides half of the stuff you guys talk about actually comes from the

If you don't agree you're life in Highschool was miserable.﻿

I think i could relate more to Korean beauty standards than North American

styled body type and cute pretty clothes.﻿

comments.text:
I can say that small face is generally more desirable in Asia. If I'm not 
mistaken, people in korea, China, japan, and Indonesia love high cheekbones 
and v-line. I myself love it too, But I think I love every shape haha. And 
Asian love bright (if not white) skin not because they want to be Caucasian 
(not because of post colonial) , but bright skin means we don't work under 
the sun (considered as wealthy people). Some people in the west love to tan 
their skin, why? I heard that they have naturally fairer skin and they 
don't live in tropical area, so tanner skin is more desirable. Is it true? 
I don't know, I just write what I heard. Maybe some of you can give me 
information about it. I try to love every skin color and every shape (I 
born in the world of standardized beauty. I can't say that I'm not 
influenced at all). A certain nationality's beauty standard is nor good or 
bad, it's just constructed by some reason. I'm sorry for my english and if 
my opinion is offensive. ﻿

comments.author: ordinaryT

comments.text:
Let me round this up for you:

Korean beauty standards: Big, round eyes w/ double eyelids, pale, porcelain 
skin, petite build and very thin body, and small face.

Western beauty standards: Big boobs and butt, curvy but skinny body, 
glowing tan, and relatively tall.

Both beauty standards are quite high, but, as corny as it sounds, I believe 
that we should all accept who we are and who everyone around us are.  It 
doesn't matter if you're curvy or skinny, tan or pale, tall or short, or 
small-eyed or big-eyed.  What matters is that you don't care about any 
"beauty standards" and don't feel disappointed when you can't/don't live up 
to those standards.  Many of those standards are unrealistic, Korean girls 
do a lot of plastic surgery (not all), and Westerners use photo shop and 
makeup a lot.  You don't have to be stick thin and look like a barbie doll 
to be beautiful.  And if you think you do, you either need some 
explanations or counseling.﻿

comments.text:
What they said is very true about Korean beauty standards. There literally 
is a mental checklist of the "perfect" physical traits many (and i mean 
MANY) people in Korea have in mind. I'm not joking, even many guys 
emphasize their appearance as much as girls do there. I'm not saying that 
there are no beauty standards in America or American guys don't care about 
their looks- what I'm saying is that beauty is stressed in Korea so much to 
the point that even I, as a Korean, am extremely disgusted by it. You need 
a v-line jaw, big doll-like eyes, milky white and dewy skin, a flat face 
with no dimension (bc it'd "make you look old" duh), big boobs, long 
straight legs-- all of those requirements to be seen as "pretty" in today's 
Korean society. Because of this emphasis of beauty standards and this 
pressure to fit in, SO many people are doing plastic surgery and 
unhealthily idolize those who do meet those requirements. And what's sad is 
that, when you walk in the streets of Korea, you'll notice so many girls 
who look alike (because they all did surgery to achieve that "perfect 
look") and a lot of people don't embrace their individuality. ﻿
comments.author: jiah k

comments.text:
I'm from India and I find these Beauty standards quite weird because

Your wide nose may unbalance your face (well, at least that's what mine

comments.author: Cordelia Enid H

comments.text:
+khyoon14 What I meant to say is that while technically almost all faces

heavily distorted, nobody will notice, so what difference does it make? 
I hate my sqare jawline and my wide nose, but I'm not at all cocerned about 
my differently-sized nostrils....
comments.author: Scuro1000

comments.text:
+Scuro1000 you have to have an eye to see symmetry. My face is definitely 
not. jawline is different from one side to the other. one eye is ever so 
slightly bigger, the middle of my teeth are offset from the center of my 
nose, and lastly the shape of my temples are different from each other. LOL 
it's hilarious. Most people won't see it though.
comments.author: khyoon14

comments.text:
+Scuro1000 Well actually what you say about your nostrils not being 
identical is exactly what the idea of facial symmetry is all about.

Unconsciously people recognize how symmetrical a face is. Literally how 
much one side of your face looks like the other side. The more both sides 
are equal, the healthier, therefore the more attractive that face is 
considered. 

Looking at the average person closely you'll see that their eyes may be 
slightly different sizes or not perfectly aligned, their cheeks may not be 
the same size or in the same place. It sounds bizarre, but its perfectly 
normal. It is people with near perfect symmetry that are unusual. That is 
why they're seen as more attractive than the normal person.

For instance, Tom Cruise has a very symmetrical face, in fact many celebs 
do, and of course models.

Generally regardless of race or ethnicity, health, symmetry and a 
particular ratio as far as feature placement are what really determine 
general "attractiveness".
comments.author: Jayjen35

comments.text:

comments.author: imaprouduclabruin

comments.text:
+Choi Minki I would have to seriously disagree with the implications of 
this.

Even if it may not seem as "cut and dry", America actually has very 
specific beauty standards if you pay attention in pop culture, as can be 
seen in exactly those women you pointed out. All four of them have an 
incredibly similar facial structure: small but defined chin and jaw, thick 
lips, high cheek bones, thin cheeks, large upturned eyes, minimal brow 
bone, medium-large forehead, medium-small sized nose*, etc. Not to mention 
the perfect skin, large straight white teeth, etc. As far as body structure 
goes, they all share long necks, narrow/slim shoulders (Lupita's are 
pushing it), long legs, and dramatically fit one of the three socially 
acceptable body types (athletic, thin, or curvy). Men also have a very 
clear beauty standard in American pop culture.

*The only real difference between the kind of popular beauty standards 
America has compared to Korea is that our racial diversity forces us to 
have a little more respect and leniency for other races and may turn a 
blind eye when a black woman has a slightly larger nose, or a Caucasian has 
thinner lips, or an Asian has wider cheeks bones, etc.

I do understand what you're trying to say, though. America has people of so 
many different races in pop culture that it creates an illusion of there 
being less strict of a mold as far as beauty standards go, and Americans 
are obviously much less gung-ho about getting surgery to fit it. People 
aren't quite as open about any obsessions they may have with their 
appearance because vanity is seen in a very negative light beyond the big 
cities. Cosmetic surgery is also frowned upon in many areas of America to 
the point where you may be treated poorly or assumed to be mentally unwell 
if you go through with it.

There are a lot of variables that factor into why we haven't fallen quite 
as hard a Korea has with all that nonsense, but the standards themselves 
are definitely there.
comments.author: deadbride9

Taylor Swift, or Nicki Minaj, or Lupita Nyongo. We still HAVE beauty 
standards, we just don't have that one SUPREME beauty standard that trumps 
all.

We in the West definitely have general beauty traits that we prefer..for 
example, mostly guys with strong jaws and athletic bodies are more 'manly' 
and attractive. Rarely we find guys with soft jaws and unfit bodies 'hot'. 
And girls....long legs, tiny waist, boobs, 'healthy tan', high cheekbones, 
big lips, long hair....you get the idea lol. We have an entire list.
I mean, yea you have individuals who disagree, but generally we understand 
people being what we call "objectively attractive", and that, ladies and 
gentlemen, is what our beauty standards are, and they are definitely at 
work in our society.
Just look at at all the girls and their insecurities. We're so in denial 
sometimes, talking about "what's inside", that admitting our own vanity and 
judgement of others is almost a taboo.﻿
